item.title: Power Shift in Syria Upends an Archipelago for ISIS Prisoners
item.description: America’s Kurdish allies oversaw two dozen sites holding thousands of members of the terrorist group and their families. Their withdrawal has left the system in chaos.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Hussam Hammoud and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: At These Gaza Schools, ‘Peace Building’ Is Part of the Curriculum
item.description: A fast-growing network of private schools, the brainchild of a North Carolina neurosurgeon, is teaching 9,000 war orphans and other needy Palestinian youngsters.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger, Bilal Shbair and Saher Alghorra
item.media:description: Students lining up to enter a classroom at an Academy of Hope school in Deir al-Balah, in the central Gaza Strip, this month.

item.title: A Road Trip from Kandahar to Kabul on Highway 1 in Afghanistan
item.description: Life and business are back along a road once defined by war damage. But even with improved security, Afghans are desperate for jobs and development.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Tomás Munita
item.media:credit: Tomás Munita for The New York Times

item.title: Botswana’s ‘Corn Lady’ Finds Fame With Food Stands
item.description: Tshephiso Marumo has had success selling traditional village food in Botswana. But as she has risen, she has become more outspoken, inviting backlash.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon, Yvonne Mooka and Joao Silva

item.title: Talks on Russia-Ukraine War Enter 2nd Day in Geneva
item.description: The discussions in Geneva were expected to focus on territorial issues, a major sticking point, but the short duration suggests major progress was not made.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Russia’s lead negotiator, Vladimir Medinsky, in Geneva on Tuesday.

item.title: The Behind the Scenes Search for Compromise on Territory in Ukraine Talks
item.description: The latest round of talks ended with no indication of progress, but negotiators are bargaining over who will control land in eastern Ukraine if they reach a settlement.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Soldiers monitor the sky for Russian drones in the Donetsk region of Ukraine in December.

item.title: South Sudan Appoints Dead Man to Election Panel, as Political Crisis Grows
item.description: The government of President Salva Kiir has been accused of gross incompetence, as fighting between rebels and security forces pushes toward the capital.
item.dc:creator: Brian O. Otieno and Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Critics accuse the government of President Salva Kiir, seen at center on a billboard in Juba, South Sudan, in 2024, of gross incompetence.

item.title: Alberto Tomba Was an ’80s and ’90s Icon. The Olympics Have Brought Him Back.
item.description: Nicknamed “Tomba la Bomba,” the Italian skier was a global superstar before he drifted from the limelight. Decades later, the Winter Games have given him a new platform.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alberto Tomba in the wine cellar at his home near Bologna, Italy, last month. An Olympic medal winner in the 1980s and ’90s, he is back in the limelight for the Milan-Cortina games.

item.title: Russia’s Exile From World Sports Will End Next Month at Paralympics
item.description: Six Russian athletes and four Belarusians will be allowed to represent their nations, officials said. The decision could pave the way for a Russian team to compete at the 2028 Summer Games in Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian athletes carrying their national flag at the closing ceremony for the Winter Games in Sochi, Russia, in 2014.

item.title: Ski Mountaineering Makes Its Olympic Debut at the Milan-Cortina Winter Games
item.description: Ski mountaineering tests strength and endurance as athletes race uphill on skis and on foot before going back down.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Jonathon Selkowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: In ski mountaineering, competitors climb uphill on skis and then on foot before racing downhill.

item.title: Iranians Mourn Slain Protesters With ‘Revolutionary Rage’
item.description: The authorities moved to suppress shows of defiance at ceremonies commemorating 40 days since the death of protesters.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Leily Nikounazar, Sanjana Varghese and Jon Hazell
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Obtained by The New York Times

item.title: Spain to Investigate Social Media Giants, Escalating Trans-Atlantic Tech Dispute
item.description: The government wants prosecutors to investigate X, Meta and TikTok, adding to a growing clash between the U.S. and Europe over regulating social media.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain in Madrid last month. He asked prosecutors to investigate X, Meta, and TikTok for the spread of child sex abuse material on the platforms.

item.title: A Rio Carnival Party That Goes On and On
item.description: The Boi Tolo, one of the city’s most iconic street parties, has come to represent the glittery, gritty grass-roots celebration far from the glamour of the official parades.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova and Dado Galdieri
item.media:description: Revelers taking part in the Boi Tolo on Sunday in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Peru Votes to Impeach President José Jerí
item.description: Peru’s Congress voted to impeach President José Jerí, four months after he replaced Dina Boluarte, who had also been removed from the presidency.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Mitra Taj
item.media:description: José Jerí was sworn in last October as interim president, replacing Dina Boluarte.

item.title: Yoon’s martial law declaration failed, but his supporters stayed loyal.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally for former President Yoon Suk Yeol in Seoul last year.

item.title: Yoon’s jail cell is a world away from his presidential mansion.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A television screen at a train station in Seoul showing former President Yoon Suk Yeol in December.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.description: After months of political turmoil over former President Yoon Suk Yeol’s imposition of martial law, his trial harkens back to the chaotic days after South Koreans ousted a junta and enshrined democracy.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun

item.title: These Olympians Excel on Two Types of Tracks
item.description: Among elite athletes exists an even more exclusive club: people who compete at both the Summer and Winter Games. Many are sprinters who turn to bobsled.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Salomé Kora, left, will compete for a Swiss two-woman bobsled team this week in Cortina d’Ampezzo, Italy.

item.title: Policy Flip-Flops Hurt the British Leader. Then Came a New Political Threat.
item.description: Already weakened by “U-turns” on his agenda, Prime Minister Keir Starmer faced calls to step down over appointing a close friend of Jeffrey Epstein as U.S. ambassador.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain speaking at a community center in Welwyn Garden City, Britain, last week.

item.title: Russia Celebrated Him. Now He’s Accused of Having Troops Shoot Themselves.
item.description: A lieutenant colonel is on trial after being accused of skimming payments for battlefield injuries. He denies the specifics of Russia’s accusation but acknowledges engaging in a payouts scheme.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Ksenia Churmanova
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A recruitment poster in Moscow last year. The military has struggled to root out endemic corruption.

item.title: What To Know About the Trial of Yoon Suk Yeol, South Korea’s Ousted Leader
item.description: Former President Yoon Suk Yeol was sentenced to life imprisonment after being found guilty on Thursday of leading an insurrection with his short-lived imposition of martial law in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yoon Suk Yeol in Seoul in 2022.

item.title: Israel’s Actions Questioned at Security Council Meeting
item.description: Amid criticism over the board’s structure and broad mandate, the U.S. ambassador to the U.N. defended the board, saying “a new way” was needed to address the situation in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Waltz, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, at the Security Council last month. Mr. Waltz said President Trump’s Board of Peace planned to pledge $5 billion to the reconstruction and rehabilitation of Gaza.

item.title: As Trump Weighs Possible Iran Strikes, U.S. Military Moves Into Place
item.description: President Trump has given no indication that he has made a decision about how to proceed, as diplomatic talks continue.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The U.S.S. Gerald R. Ford aircraft carrier, seen here in the North Sea last year, is making its way toward the Middle East.

item.title: After Activist’s Killing, Tensions Erupt Between France’s Far-Right and Far-Left
item.description: The beating death of Quentin Deranque has quickly become a flashpoint between the far right and far left as France prepares for local elections next month and presidential elections next year.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: An area near the site of the brawl in Lyon, France, that led to the beating death of Quentin Deranque, on Saturday.

item.title: Journalists Arrested in Cameroon While Covering Secretive U.S. Deportations
item.description: An Associated Press reporter was hit and held with three other journalists and a lawyer, two detainees said, while at a center for migrants secretively deported from the United States.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: The compound where deportees from the United States were being held in Yaoundé, Cameroon.

item.title: The Country Betting on Immigrants
item.description: Spain may have a solution to the backlash against migrants in many wealthy countries.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Venezuelan food stall in Madrid.

item.title: An Antarctic Expedition Ends in New Zealand
item.description: But stay tuned: We’ve still got more to share about this Antarctic expedition, and the next ones scientists are already planning.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The New Zealand coast seen from the icebreaker Araon as it neared the end of its journey on Thursday.

item.title: Mikaela Shiffrin exorcises ghost of Olympic past.
item.description: After failing to medal in 2022, Shiffrin rebounded to win gold in slalom.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and James Hill
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Bets on Diplomacy Without Diplomats
item.description: President Trump’s most trusted envoys, Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, are at the center of the Iran and Ukraine negotiations.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner in Israel last October.

item.title: Triple the pressure, triple the glory.
item.description: Ami Nakai of Japan leads after the short program ahead of a talented field, including the American Alysa Liu, who is third.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Doug Mills

item.title: From 1983: Fania Fénelon, 74; Memoirs Described Auschwitz Singing
item.description: In “Playing for Time,” she recounted how singing in an all-female orchestra while in a concentration camp saved her from death.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: From 1966: Anna Akhmatova, Leading Soviet Poet, Is Dead
item.description: She was a towering figure in Soviet literature who was once silenced in a Stalinist literary purge.
item.dc:creator: Special to The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Akhmatova in the late 1920s.

item.title: From 2009: Millvina Dean, Titanic’s Last Survivor, Dies at 97
item.description: She was just 9 weeks old when she was lowered to safety in a mail sack, surviving the worst maritime disaster in history.
item.dc:creator: John F. Burns
item.media:description: Millvina Dean in 1994 peering through a porthole that was part of an exhibit called “The Wreck of the Titanic” at the National Maritime Museum.

item.title: Labubu Diplomacy
item.description: China seems to be winning more hearts and minds abroad. Has it gotten better at soft power?
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: In Africa, Jesse Jackson Was Esteemed for His Fight Against Apartheid
item.description: He made several trips to South Africa, and to other African nations, as a peace broker and a representative of Black America.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Jesse Jackson with Nelson Mandela in Johannesburg in 2005.

item.title: Question of True Remorse When A.I. Helps Write Your Court Apology
item.description: The use of artificial intelligence gave a New Zealand judge pause about the genuineness of the remorse expressed in the apology. It reflects a wider discussion about using A.I. for personal communication.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: The arson case was heard in the District Court in Christchurch, New Zealand.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’ Presses Hamas on Disarmament, Officials Say
item.description: The direct talks last week came as officials urgently try to find a breakthrough on the issue of Hamas’s weapons, fearing the cease-fire in Gaza could collapse.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamas militants searching for the bodies of remaining hostages north of Gaza City, in December.

item.title: Frederick Vreeland, Diplomat and Spy Who Served With Style, Dies at 98
item.description: A son of the influential fashion editor Diana Vreeland, he had an upbringing well suited to his overt and covert duties during the Cold War.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: Palmerston, the Former ‘Chief Mouser’ for Britain’s Foreign Office, Dies
item.description: The cat, who was named after a former prime minister, became a social media star. By the time of his death at about 12, he had more followers than many ambassadors have.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Palmerston sitting on a photographer’s ladder at Downing Street in London, in 2019.

item.title: A Deadly Medieval Path in England Claims a Modern Victim: An Amazon Van
item.description: The Broomway in Essex is notoriously treacherous because of the quick-moving waters surrounding it. One delivery vehicle didn’t make it.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Neal Threadgold/HM Coastguard Southend on Sea
item.media:description: An Amazon delivery van was stranded on Sunday after its driver mistakenly steered onto the Broomway, a six-mile path out into the Thames Estuary in England.

item.title: Parents of Some Winter Olympians Face Extreme Fear as Their Children Compete
item.description: When your child races headfirst down an ice chute, leaps off ski jumps or performs snowboard tricks in midair, a medal may not be the main thing you pray for.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight, Kim Severson and Bedel Saget
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/ The New York Times
item.media:description: Christine and Mark Henderson watched their daughter, Grace Henderson, compete in the women’s freestyle skiing big air qualifiers during the 2026 Winter Olympics.

item.title: Lunar New Year in Photos and Video: Revelers Welcome Year of the Horse
item.description: The Lunar New Year, the most important holiday in many Asian countries, is being celebrated around the world.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Lion dancers performing at a furniture shop during Lunar New Year celebrations at Chinatown in Manila on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump’s Ambassador to Belgium Is Summoned After Accusing Officials of Antisemitism
item.description: The diplomat, Bill White, met with a foreign ministry official at a time of rising tensions between the U.S. and countries in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek and Koba Ryckewaert
item.media:credit: Kurt Desplenter/Belga, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Bill White, the U.S. ambassador to Belgium, met on Tuesday with Belgian officials over his social media posts.

item.title: Austria Charges Man in Thwarted Attack on Taylor Swift Concert
item.description: The foiled plot led to the cancellation of three shows in 2024 that Ms. Swift had planned for Austria during her Eras tour.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Police officers watching as Taylor Swift fans gather in Vienna in 2024.

item.title: The Drone Games: Flying Cameras Are Everywhere at the Winter Olympics
item.description: The robotic cameras chase behind lugers, skiers and speedskaters across the venues in Northern Italy. Some spectators find they’re as much fun to watch as the athletes.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: A drone video camera following speedskaters during the women’s 500-meter race at the Milan Olympics, on Sunday.

item.title: Trump Said He’d End the War in Ukraine in a Day. It’s Harder Than He Thought.
item.description: Russian attacks and Ukrainian civilian deaths rose as President Trump’s peace talks dragged on during his first year back in the White House.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: An apartment building that a Russian missile struck in Kyiv, Ukraine, in August. Moscow’s attacks have inflicted a growing toll on Ukrainians.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia Hold New Round of Peace Talks, but Expectations Are Low
item.description: Both sides described previous U.S.-mediated negotiations as productive, although they did not appear to address sticking points like territory and security guarantees.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery brigade firing in the Zaporizhzhia region of eastern Ukraine in October. The conflict will enter its fifth year later this month.

item.title: Questions Swirl Around Russian Figure Skater in Her Olympic Debut
item.description: Adeliia Petrosian, 18, has the résumé of a medal contender — and ties to coaches and a skater who were at the center of a doping scandal at the last Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:description: Adeliia Petrosian has skated outside Russia only once since 2022. She makes her Olympic debut on Tuesday at the Winter Games in Milan.

item.title: After Trip to Germany, AOC Expresses Frustrations
item.description: The congresswoman argued in an interview that presidential speculation, which included scrutiny of her slip-ups, had overshadowed her anti-authoritarian message at the Munich Security Conference.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez used her trip to Germany to argue that the best way to counteract far-right movements was to address people’s economic struggles.

item.title: Japan Wins Pairs Figure Skating, Knocking China From the Top
item.description: Riku Miura and Ryuichi Kihara of Japan emerged with the gold medal with a flawless, high-scoring performance after Monday’s free skate.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather, Doug Mills and Vincent Alban

item.title: Auditioning to Beat Trump
item.description: Democrats like A.O.C. are testing out their messages in Europe before the midterms.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: ‘Tina’ and ‘Milo’ Olympic Mascot Toys Are Almost as Tough to Get as a Medal
item.description: Fans have fallen hard for plush dolls representing Tina and Milo, the mascots of Italy’s Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.media:description: Tina, the Winter Olympics mascot, has been a hot commodity.

item.title: Iran Holds Exercises in Strait of Hormuz After Trump Threatens Military Action
item.description: The day before nuclear talks were set to resume, Iran conducted live drills in the Strait of Hormuz, a strategic waterway for oil and gas shipments.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:description: The island of Qeshm, in the Strait of Hormuz. The strait is a key shipping lane for oil and gas and connects the Persian Gulf to the open ocean.

item.title: How Spain Is Carving a Different Path on Immigration
item.description: The country is hoping its new amnesty for undocumented immigrants will avoid a public backlash.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub and José Bautista
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up outside a Venezuelan Consulate in Madrid last month.

item.title: In Hungary, Marco Rubio Stresses Trump’s Support for Viktor Orban
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state said in Budapest that the president was “deeply committed” to the success of Viktor Orban, who has boasted of creating an “illiberal state.”
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio in Budapest on Monday with Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary. Mr. Orban is facing a potentially tough challenge in national elections in April.

item.title: Ticket Scam Cost the Louvre $12 Million, Investigators Say
item.description: The Paris prosecutor’s office said a network involving museum employees and tour guides had been operating for a decade.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investigators said the suspected scam at the Louvre museum in Paris involved tour guides reusing tickets for different people.

item.title: User Issues With X Appear to Have Resolved
item.description: The social media site was the subject of user complaints early Monday.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: Dana Eden, Co-Creator of ‘Tehran,’ Dies During Filming of Fourth Season
item.description: Ms. Eden, 52, who was also an executive producer of the Emmy-winning show, was found in a hotel room in Athens. Greek police said they did not suspect foul play.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Dana Eden at the premier of Season 2 of “Tehran” in New York in 2022.

item.title: Syrian Army Crosses New Threshold With Advances in Kurdish Regions
item.description: The advance of the Syrian Army into Kurdish regions could put nearly all the country under one authority. But it ends a dream of autonomy for ethnic Kurds.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Hussam Hammoud and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The Syrian Army has moved into vast new regions, seeking to erase the largest fissure left from the civil war.
